final_translation: The future is unpredictable; it gives birth to a child and names it "Wealth is Worrisome."
The size of the rat determines the size of the trap; a wise person does not act recklessly.
The bird that compares itself to a vulture sleeps behind the kitchen
The trickster claims to know the way; who would dare follow the path of a trickster?
Do not rely on the host, do not rely on the guest; it is one's own hand that one should rely on.
Masquerades surpass masquerades; deities surpass deities; the Pààká (a type of masquerade) outshines the Sango worshipper.
“I am full” means “I am full,” “I am not full” means “I am not full”; eating secretly is the behavior of a greedy elder.
An elder does not finish eating and say they will eat more
The person we sell and use the money to buy a machete says the machete is causing them suffering.
Instead of bowing down to Gàm̀bàrí, we would rather endure and die.
Inability to remove oneself from a situation is what kills the monkey; inability to remove oneself is what kills the fly; inability to remove oneself is what kills the antelope.
One does not use a finger to measure the ear, then use it to measure the nose, and then use it to count the teeth.
The sack behaves like a load, the bone behaves like meat
A disrespectful head of the household encounters disgrace on the way
An elder who does not greet the president is digging his own grave.
Without effort, the axe cannot cut; if we exert effort, even a cotton child can cut wood.
Where one places oneself is where one will find comfort
If the royal messenger wants to fail, what can the king do?
A slave does not eat what is not sold in the market.
The hawk does not carry a chick while holding an insect.
After discussing strategies and wisdom, it is "I don't want, I won't accept" that a fool uses to end a matter.
The person we love is different from the one who claims there is no one like them.
A person who is deceitful will eventually be exposed.
A rope that is long enough to tie a palm tree is not necessarily strong enough to restrain a horse; a rope that can restrain a horse is the one that is strong and durable.
When pounding yam, the toes must get smeared.
A child who has never tasted soup is scooping oil into their pocket
A father's hand does not become a child's hand
It is appropriate for everyone to show some restraint in mourning, but not for the one who has suffered the loss.
The damage of one day does not ruin a lifetime
Where stories are being told before inheritance, it is important to know that the inheritance is not significant.
If the head of the household is struggling, the junior ones should carry firewood.
The dandy walks briskly in the market, while the slovenly person walks sluggishly; yet it is the slovenly person who helps carry the dandy's load home.
The maggot and the ant are digging, they claim they are going to catch a runaway chicken, but we haven't seen the evidence.
The pig is not praiseworthy
The rope that is strong enough to tie a palm tree is not strong enough to stop an elephant; the tether that tells the elephant not to climb the savannah hill, the elephant says it is going there.
The extinguisher that says it will put out the lamp will extinguish itself.
An old crab that is put into a wide container feels ashamed.
"We called you the child of a laughing hyena, and you are smiling; are you the one we are referring to?"
The wealthy walk with the rich; peers play with peers.
Let the servant know themselves as a servant; let the apprentice know themselves as an apprentice; let a person of good character know themselves as a servant of God, the King.
One cannot be wiser than the person for whom divination is being performed
What is Àmọdù doing in Ilorin? A goat is eating there.
One who claims to be gentle like a dove but makes a lot of noise.
One who plays the dundun drum does not dance
A person with only one cloth does not go near the fire
The day an elder dies is better than the day an elder falls into disgrace
A bird cannot drink the water inside a coconut
The phrase 'I know it all' is what ruins a man
When we are arranging the corn, we do not arrange the chaff with it
Your younger sibling is sewing clothes for you, and you say you don't wear rags; who then wears bean cakes?
If there were no good people, who would wake up in the morning without covering their face in shame?
Respect is given to 'Mother of the Town'; there is no mother in the town without a name.
When the stew is delicious, we find something to talk about
Excess is the father of inadequacy; inadequacy is the end result of excess; an elder who wears the garment of excess will end up with inadequacy.
We only have to pound yam once; every day the eyes face challenges.
One does not keep silent and still speak; one does not watch and still commit a crime.
As you know, the bean seller at Ṣàpón.
Everyone cries for Bánjọ, but Bánjọ does not cry for himself.
It is with the sword of a miser that a miser is killed
The food of a small child can enter an elder's stomach; but a small child's ring cannot fit an elder's finger.
‘Pull it inside’ is appropriate for the horse rider
A dog does not venture into the wilderness to hunt a leopard
The reformer knows how to reform himself
A big scar often leads to a fight
Today, the duiker is elusive, tomorrow, the duiker is elusive; is the duiker the only animal in the forest?
A wife who beats another person's child is seeking to hear some words
The day I will arrive, I have never seen its kind before: your master knows your limits.
It is better not to accept a chieftaincy title than to say, "I cannot handle the responsibilities of the community."
Borrowed clothes do not befit one; borrowed trousers do not suit a person; if it does not trip you, it will make you stumble; what truly suits a person is what belongs to them.
What did Dáàró do before claiming that a thief robbed him?
The pig is going to the market, and it asks, 'Is it three hundred or six hundred?' Which one do you carry there?
The head of a household does not become so blind that he uses his hands to feel his way around his own house.

"Greeting 'Ẹ kú-ulé' is not necessary for those at home; 'Ẹ kú atìbà' is not needed for someone who is running for cover; the person who does not greet others with 'Kú atìbà' will miss out on 'Ẹ kú-ulé.'"
What kind of meat have we not eaten before? When a frog meets you in the swamp, it becomes a serious matter.
The one who is intensely angry seeks food for the one who is mildly angry.
The mud of Ìjèṣà, it splashes on you but does not stain.
Who is eating that the fish is getting spoiled?
"The refined person eats the drumstick; the wise person eats the kola nut; the one who eats indiscriminately eats the chaff."
If we do not properly measure the suffering we are enduring, we end up experiencing additional suffering.
One does not worship the deity with empty hands; if it gets late, one will spread a mat.
It is the future that matters
An elder who is not physically strong is wise in mind
While the back of your garment is being torn, the front is also being torn.
A tilapia gave birth to me, a leopard raised me, a lion trained me; if there is no meat in the soup, I won't eat.
After eating, not being prepared, and using all ten fingers to eat is not appropriate for a person.
Darkness does not recognize a person; it consults the oracle for "Who are you?"
When the wife and husband are in agreement, the mediator steps aside
He who is being carried like a cripple will eventually harm himself
Haste does not yield results
Whoever closes their eyes will cover their nose
The one who braids hair with beads is plentiful; if the bead owner were to charge, it wouldn't be easy to braid with beads.
We arrive as far as we know; one without a guide does not reach the destination.
Knowing one's limits does not lead to disgrace
One does not walk with the king and have the king's horse trample on them.
If the elder blows sand into the nose, the chicken will not peck.
An elder handles matters with what is left undone
Poverty does not hold anyone captive; suffering does not consume a person; if you walk the path of poverty and face hardship, you will be given water to drink in a calabash.
Sun, set so that we do not speak ill of the Creator
I have grown old and experienced, yet the antics of a child are not beyond me.
A single woman does not settle a dispute
The eye has never seen honor/wealth; it had a child and named it "Honor/wealth is a good thing."
The size of the rat determines the size of the trap; a cat does not carry what is too heavy for it.
A bird that compares itself to a vulture ends up sleeping behind a trash heap.
"The mosquito claims it can block the path; who would follow the path of a mosquito?"
"Don't lean on the host, don't lean on the visitor; one should lean on oneself."
One masquerade surpasses another masquerade; one deity surpasses another deity; [But] Pààká (leopard) makes the Sango worshipper run into the bush.
"I am full" means "I am full," "I refuse" means "I refuse"; eating and still wanting more is the behavior of a greedy elder.
An elder doesn't wash their hands and then say they will eat later.
The person who was sold and whose money was used to buy a machete says the machete is causing him suffering.
Rather than prostrate (bow down) to a Hausa man (Gambari), it's better to be brave and die.
"Refusal to leave (or persistence) is what kills the mosquito; refusal to leave is what kills the moth; refusal to leave is what kills the housefly."
One does not use the same finger to clean the ear, clean the nose, and then pick the teeth.
"Saki (a type of cloth/garment) pretends to be velvet, masquerade pretends to be flesh."
It is the hasty/impatient landlord who meets disrespect on the way.
An elder who doesn't greet the king is preparing the rope for his own funeral.
"It is due to lack of strength that the machete doesn't cut; if one has strength, a cotton fiber can cut a tree."
Where we put our body is where the body lives/dwells.
When the palace servant wants to rebel, they ask what the king has done wrong.
A slave does not eat what is not sold in the market.
The hawk does not catch a chicken to give insects to someone else.
After discussing twenty points, after discussing thirty points, "I don't want it, I don't accept it" is how a fool ends a matter.
"The person we love is different from the one who says there is nobody like them."
A slanderer is the one who looks at you with contempt.

A rope that is long enough to tie a palm tree is not enough to stop an elephant from going; a rope that claims it can stop an elephant from going to Alo, both the rope and the elephant will go together.
When pounding yam, the pestle will eventually come out.
A child who has never tasted soup/stew before smears palm oil on their chest.
What is in the father's hand does not easily transfer to the child's hand.
"It is fitting for everyone to reduce expenses on indigo dye, but it is not fitting for the dyer."
The troubles of one day do not end easily/quickly.
Before inheriting property, one should first know the history behind it, so that the inheritance doesn't become a curse.
When the household head is misbehaving (or acting foolishly), one reprimands the servant instead.
A proud person enters the market walking majestically, a filthy person enters the market walking slowly; it is the filthy person who carries the proud person's load home.
The cockroach and the ant set out on a journey, saying they were going to catch a hen that went out but never returned.
The pig doesn't know beauty.
A chain as tall as a palm tree cannot stop an elephant; yet the creeping plant that tells the elephant not to climb the ọ̀dàn tree goes along with the elephant.
"The wind that boasts it will extinguish the lamp will only destroy itself."
An elderly crab that jumps into a basin suddenly feels embarrassed.
"You're called an elephant child, yet you can't lift it; are you the one who swallowed it?"
The wealthy associates with the rich; peers play with peers.
Let the slave know themselves as a slave; let the pawn know themselves as a pawn; let the person of good character know themselves as a servant of God the king.
One cannot be wiser than the person for whom one is consulting the oracle.
What are they doing to Amodu in Ilorin? The goat is eating like that.
One who is created without ability is like a dove that makes the sound "bem-be".
One who beats the dundun drum does not start the song.
A person with only one garment does not spread it out carelessly in the sun.
The day an elder dies is better than the day an elder is disgraced.
A bird cannot drink water from inside a coconut.
"I know him completely" is how Death carries away a man.
"When we are arranging corn, we do not arrange palm kernels alongside it."
Your younger sibling offers to make clothes for you, and you complain that they don't use quality fabric; who uses the bread seller's fabric?
If it were not for human desires/aspirations, who would wake up early in the morning and not wash their face?
Mother-of-So-and-So' is a title of respect; there is no mother who bears a child that doesn't earn a name.
If the fire burns the soup, a discussion will arise.
Excess is the father of shame; shame follows excess; an elder who indulges in excess will end up in shame.
You feel shame only once; but embarrassment troubles you daily.
One should not keep silent and be misunderstood; one should not just stare and be found guilty.
Do as you know how to, beautiful one of Shapon.
Everyone weeps for Banjo; but Banjo does not weep for himself.
It is the tortoise's sword that is used to kill the tortoise.
A child's food can fit into an elder's stomach; but a child's ring cannot fit on an elder's finger.
Pull him inside' is appropriate for a horseman.
A dog does not go into the deep forest to hunt a leopard/tiger.
The person who has done wrong knows their own wrongdoing.
A big slap leads to a fight.
"Today, duiker meat for dinner, tomorrow, duiker meat again; is duiker the only animal in the forest?"
A wife who beats her stepchild is asking for trouble.
Since I've been worshipping, I've never seen its kind: the owner/deity knows its own limits.
Not being crowned king at all is better than saying "My voice doesn't command the town."
Wasteful spending doesn't suit a person; wearing oversized trousers doesn't suit someone; if it doesn't fit your legs, it becomes baggy; what belongs to you is what suits you.
"What did Daaro have before claiming to have been robbed?"
The person buying pork asks, "Is it 1,500 naira worth of pork or 1,200 naira worth?" Which one did you take from there?
No matter how embarrassed the head of a household is, he doesn't sweep his own house with his hands.

Welcome to the house' is not appropriate for household members; 'Welcome from your journey' is not fitting for someone returning from a trip; the person who doesn't greet others with 'Welcome from your journey' will miss out on receiving 'Welcome to the house.
"What animal have we not eaten before? The toad met us wearing shoes and it ruined everything."
The one who gets angry and then calms down quickly is the one who finds food for the one who gets angry and stays angry for a long time.
The light drizzle of Ijesa, it touches one's body but costs nothing.
Who is eating while the dog is staring hungrily?
"It is the sophisticated person who eats palm kernel; it is the wise person who eats kola nut; it is the careless person who eats walnut."
"If we don't learn from the suffering we're meant to learn from, we'll end up suffering endlessly."
One does not worship a deity during the harmattan season; when the rainy season arrives, the altar will be rebuilt.
It depends
An elder who doesn't have feet on the ground has wisdom inside.
We are tearing the cloth at the back, while it's also tearing at the front.
I was born to the leopard clan, raised by a tiger, and adopted by a cat; if there is no meat in the stew, I will not eat.
After finishing eating, pretending not to be satisfied, and eating with ten fingers is not befitting of a human being.
Darkness does not recognize anyone; it cast Ifa divination for 'Is that you?
"When a wife respects her husband, the intruder/meddler will back away."
The person who is being raised (or carried) foolishly will end up hurting themselves.
Thinness/leanness does not equate to weakness
Whoever keeps their eyes open will see their nose.
"The owner of beads carefully threads them together; if the owner of the thread had money, it wouldn't be difficult to string beads."
One arrives according to one's means; someone without a horse does not arrive in style/grandeur.
"I know my limits" is not an expression of insult.
One cannot wrestle with the king and not expect to be kicked by the king's emissaries.
If the elder has mucus in his nose, it is not the chicken that will point it out.
The elder handles matters with caution/restraint (to avoid death).

Poverty does not come from one place; suffering does not come from one place; if you walk in poverty, if you enter a town with the face of poverty, they will give you water to drink in a broken calabash.
Let the sun set so that we don't have to blame the day's owner/controller.
I have grown old and gray, but I still appreciate the playfulness of children.
A single woman (or a woman alone) does not win a major fight.
The eye has not seen wealth; it gave birth to its child and named it "Wealth is a burden."
The measure of a rat is the measure of the trap; a carrier does not carry blindly.
The bird that imitates a vulture sleeps behind the kitchen.
A trickster claims to know the way; who would follow the path of a trickster?
Do not rely on the host, do not rely on the guest; it is on oneself that we rely.
One masquerade surpasses another; one deity surpasses another; Pààká defeats the Sango devotee.
"Saying 'I am full' means 'I am full,' and saying 'I am not full' means 'I am not full'; overeating is the behavior of a greedy elder."
An elder does not finish examining and then say he will eat more.
The person who is sold and whose money is used to buy a cutlass says the suffering of the cutlass affects them.
Rather than prostrate to Gàm̀bàrí, endure and die.
Failure to remove [the problem] kills the ẹmọ́n; failure to remove [the problem] kills the àfè; failure to remove [the problem] kills the máláàjú.
One does not scratch the ear with a finger, then use it to scratch the nose, and then use it to pick the teeth.
Things are not always as they seem.
A disrespectful person meets disgrace on the way.
An elder who does not greet the chief uses a rope to bind himself.
Without effort, the cutlass does not cut; if we exert effort, even a delicate person can cut wood.
Where we place ourselves is where we live.
If a royal servant wants to sit, what should the king do?
Except for the thing that we do not sell in the market, a slave does not eat.
A hawk does not buy a chicken and carry an insect with it.
"To speak of inheritance, to speak of wisdom, 'I don't want, I won't accept' is how a fool ends a matter."
The person we love is different from the one who claims there is no one like them.
A deceitful person hides their face.
A rope long enough for a palm tree is not enough to tell the monkey not to go; a rope that is enough to tell the monkey not to go to Àlọ́, it is the monkey that goes.
When we are pounding yam, the leg of the mortar will shake.
A child who has not tasted soup is spilling oil on their chest.
It never remains in the hand of the father and becomes the hand of the child.
It is appropriate for everyone to lessen sorrow, but not for the lazy person.
The damage of one day does not last forever.
Before we inherit from the place where stories are being told, let us know that the inheritance there is not ours.
When the head of the household is struggling, we use a stick to support the weak.

The meticulous person enters the market walking confidently, while the less concerned person enters walking unassumingly; it is the less concerned person who ends up carrying the meticulous person's load home.
The termites and ants were digging, they said they were going to catch a chicken that strayed, but we did not see the sacrifice.
The pig is not a creature of beauty
A chain tied to a palm tree is not enough to stop an elephant; a rope that tells the elephant not to climb the savannah is ineffective, as the elephant continues on its way.
The moth that says it will extinguish the lamp will destroy itself.
The elderly crab that enters a wide container is embarrassed.
We called you the child of the wise elephant, and you are the one laughing?
A wealthy person associates with another wealthy person; a peer plays with a peer.
Let the slave know himself as a slave; let the bonded servant know himself as a bonded servant; let the person of good character know himself as a servant of God the King.
One does not become wiser than the person for whom Ifá will be consulted.
What is Àmọ́dù doing in Ilorin? The goat is eating like that.
The one who claims to be as innocent as a dove makes a loud noise.
A boastful person does not laugh.
A person with only one cloth does not wear it out in one day.
The day an elder dies is better than the day an elder is disgraced.
A bird cannot see the water inside a coconut to drink.
It is "I know it all" that pride uses to carry a man.
While we are arranging the corn, we do not arrange the sorghum as well.
Your younger sibling is sewing clothes for you, and you say you don't wear elékuru; who then wears alákàrà?
If no one is perfect, who would wake up in the morning without any flaws?
Respect is due to 'Mother of the Town'; there is no mother in the town without a name.
When the fire makes the soup taste good, we create a conversation.
Excessiveness is the father of disgrace; disgrace is the end of excessiveness; an elder who wears the garment of excessiveness will end up in disgrace.
We set a trap only once; the eyes are opened every day.
One does not keep quiet and still speak; one does not just look and be guilty.
As you know, the bean seller of Ṣàpón.
Everybody is crying for Banjọ, but Banjọ does not cry for himself.
A tortoise is dealt with using a tortoise's sword.
The food of a small child can be consumed by an elder, but a small child's ring cannot fit an elder's finger.
‘Pull it inside’ is appropriate for the horse rider.
A dog does not go into the wilderness to confront a leopard.
The one responsible for the work knows how to do it themselves.
A big scar leads to a fight.
Today, the antelope falls into a pit; tomorrow, the antelope falls into a pit; is the antelope the only animal in the forest?
A wife who beats someone else's child wants to hear a word (or matter).
"The day I have been waiting for, I have never seen its like; your master knows his own limits."
Not assuming a leadership position is better than saying, "I cannot speak for the entire community."
Borrowed clothes do not fit well; borrowed trousers do not fit a person; if they do not trip you, they will be too long; what belongs to one is what suits one.
What did Dáàró have before he claimed that the thief stole from him?
The pig farmer is going with pigs, and he asks, "Is it three hundred pigs or six hundred pigs?" Which did you take there?
The head of the household is never too embarrassed to sweep his own house.
The greeting 'Ẹ kú-ulé' is not for the people of the house; 'Ẹ kú atìbà' is not for someone returning from a journey; someone who does not greet will miss out on the greeting 'Ẹ kú-ulé.
What kind of meat have we not eaten before? When a frog meets one in the mud, it becomes troublesome.
One who is intensely angry seeks food for one who is mildly angry.
The Ijesha mud splashes on you but doesn't stick.
Who is eating that the fish is smelling?
A meticulous person eats shea butter; a wise person eats kola nut; a careless person eats groundnut.
If we do not properly handle the suffering we are experiencing, we will endure additional suffering.
One does not worship the deity in vain; if done properly, it will yield results.
It is the present that matters
An elder who is not physically present is wise within.
We are tearing your loincloth at the back, it is tearing at the front.
A fish gave birth to me, a leopard raised me to maturity, a hunter trained me; if there is no meat in the soup, I do not eat.
Eating to fullness, eating without restraint, and eating greedily is not appropriate for a person.
Darkness does not recognize a person; it consults Ifá for "Who are you?"
When the wife faces the husband, the mediator will step aside.
The person we are carrying carelessly will harm themselves.
Timeliness prevents failure.
Whoever lowers their face will cover their nose.
The bead maker strings beads together; if the owner of the beads were to charge money, it would not be easy to string them.
We arrive as we know; one without a horse does not reach the destination.
Knowing one's own worth does not engage in mockery.
One does not confront a king lest the king's hoe strikes one on the leg.
If an elder sprinkles sand in the nose, the chicken will not fight.
It is the remaining task that the elder handles.

Poverty does not hold anyone from one place; suffering does not consume a person from one place. If you walk in poverty and face hardship when you enter a town, they will use a small calabash to fetch water for you to drink.
Sun, set so that we do not incur the displeasure of the Creator of the day.
I have grown and become wise, yet the friendships of my youth are not lost on me.
A woman does not settle a dispute
The eye has never seen honor/wealth, yet it gives birth to a child and names it "Honor is sweet."
The size of the rat matches the size of its nest; a lizard doesn't dwell in a tight space.
A bird that compares itself to a vulture will end up sleeping behind the chicken coop.
"The cricket claims it can clear a path; who would follow the path made by a cricket?"
"Don't depend on the landlord, don't depend on the guest; one should depend on oneself."
One masquerade surpasses another; one deity surpasses another; a leopard chases a Sango devotee into the bush.
"I am full" means "I am full," "I refuse" means "I refuse"; eating while being watchful is the mark of an elder with bad character.
An elder doesn't wash his hands thoroughly only to eat with dirty hands.
One who is sold and whose money is used to buy a cutlass complains that the cutlass is making them suffer.
Rather than prostrate for the Hausa man, it's better to be brave and die.
Knowing when to leave is what saves one from destruction.
One should not use the same finger to clean the ear, then the nose, and then pick the teeth.
The sack acts like velvet, the bone acts like meat.
The arrogant master will meet disrespect on his path.
An elder who does not respect the king is preparing for his own funeral.
"It's the lack of strength that makes a machete ineffective; if one has strength, even cotton can cut a tree."
Where we dedicate our efforts is where we prosper.
When a royal servant wants to overthrow the king, what can the king do about it?
A slave does not eat what cannot be found in the market.
A person of higher status or capability doesn't make way for someone of lesser ability to perform a task that benefits others.
You may speak twenty times, you may speak thirty times, but "I don't want it, I won't accept it" is how a fool ends a discussion.
The person who is truly loved is different from the one who claims no one is like them.
A hypocrite is the one who looks down on others.
The vine that can reach the top of the palm tree is not enough to stop the elephant from going; the vine that says the elephant should not go to Alo, it and the elephant will go together.
If we are pounding/eating pounded yam, the knee will show.
A person who has never experienced something valuable misuses or wastes resources due to ignorance.
What belongs in the father's hand does not easily pass to the child's hand.
Everyone may wish to economize on dye, but this is not appropriate for the dyer.
The consequences of a single day's misfortune don't disappear easily.
Before we inherit from a place, we should learn its history to know if that inheritance truly belongs to us.
When the master goes crazy, the servants go wild
"The elegant person enters the market walking proudly, the dirty person enters the market walking carefully; yet it is the dirty person who carries the elegant person's load home."
"The cockroach and the ant set out on a journey, claiming they were going to catch a chicken. We saw them leaving, but we never saw them return."
A pig does not recognize birds
A chain that is strong enough to hold a palm tree is not strong enough to stop an elephant; a vine that tells an elephant not to climb the savanna tree ends up going along with the elephant.
The moth that claims it will put out the lamp will only end up killing itself.
An elderly crab that completely falls into a basket feels embarrassed.
You are called the child of an elephant with thirty tusks, and you don't rejoice; are you the one carrying the weight?
The wealthy associate with the rich; peers play with their equals.
Let the slave know themselves as a slave; let the pawn know themselves as a pawn; let the person of good character know themselves as a servant of God the king.
One should not claim to know more than the person one is advising
What are they doing to Amodu in Ilorin? The goat just keeps eating.
A person who claims inability is like a dove that still manages to coo.
The drummer of the dundun does not compose the song.
A person with only one garment cannot afford to bleach it.
The day an elder dies is better than the day an elder is disgraced.
A bird cannot drink the water inside a coconut.
"I have it all figured out" is how Oro carries away men.
When we are dealing with one matter, we don't address a completely different matter at the same time.

Your younger sibling offers to make clothes for you, but you reject them claiming they're not good enough (like an ekuru seller's cloth); yet who actually wears even lower quality clothes (like those from an akara seller)?
If there were no personal benefit, who would wake up in the morning and not wash their face?
"Mother of Education" is a title of honor; there is no mother in education who doesn't have a name/reputation.
When the fire makes the soup hot, it creates conversation.
Excess is the father of disgrace; disgrace follows excess; an elder who dresses extravagantly will end in disgrace.
"We step on the ground only once in a while, but we use our eyes every day."
One should not be silent and be accused of speaking wrongly; one should not be a mere onlooker and be found guilty.
Act according to your knowledge, beauty of Ṣàpọ́n.
Everyone is crying for Banjo, but Banjo does not cry for himself.
The tortoise is killed by its own sword.
A small child's food can fit into an elder's stomach, but a small child's ring cannot fit on an elder's finger.
The horseman ought to bring his horse inside
A dog does not go into the wilderness to hunt a tiger.
One who has made mistakes knows their own mistakes.
Great thunder only brings about quarrels.
Today, duiker meat for soup; tomorrow, duiker meat for soup; is duiker the only animal in the forest?
A wife who disciplines a stepchild is looking for trouble.
"I've never seen anything like this in my life': only the owner knows its true worth."
It is better not to become a king at all than to admit that one couldn't handle the responsibilities of ruling.

Squandering money doesn't befit a person; disrespecting others doesn't befit a human being; if something is not meant for you, it will cause you to stumble; only what truly belongs to you suits you best.
What did Daaro say before claiming he was robbed?

"If we don't learn from the suffering/lesson that we are being taught, we will continue to experience endless suffering."
One does not worship the deity during times of scarcity; when prosperity comes, one will build a proper altar.

Eating excessively and without restraint, using all ten fingers to eat, is not befitting of a human being.

The pig is not praiseworthy.

"Excess is the father of disgrace; disgrace is the end of excess; an elder who wears the garment of excess will end in disgrace."

"A rope as tall as a palm tree cannot prevent an elephant from going; the rope that insists an elephant should not go to Alo will end up going along with the elephant."
When pounding yam, one's feet should not be sticking out.
A child who has never witnessed soup preparation splashes palm oil on their chest.
A father's burden should not become his child's responsibility.
"It is fitting for everyone to advocate for lower prices of indigo dye, but not fitting for the dyer."
The misfortune of a single day doesn't end quickly.
When one must listen to lengthy explanations before receiving an inheritance, know that such an inheritance is not meant for you.
If the head of the household is behaving wildly, we deal with his followers through the roof beams.
The elegant person enters the market walking majestically, while the dirty person enters the market walking slowly; yet it is the dirty person who carries the elegant person's load home.
"Cockroach and ant set out on a journey, claiming they were going to catch a flying chicken; we saw them depart but never saw them return."
The pig does not know birds.
A chain as tall as a palm tree cannot stop an elephant; the rope that forbids the elephant from climbing the ọ̀dàn tree ends up going along with the elephant.
The wind that boasts it will extinguish the lamp will only burn itself.
"An elderly person who mixes fermented guinea corn into a calabash of bananas feels ashamed."
"They call you the offspring of an elephant that cannot trumpet; are you the one who even swallows the trumpet?"
The wealthy person walks with the prosperous; peers play with peers.
"Let the slave recognize their position as a slave; let the indentured servant recognize their position as such; let the person of good character recognize themselves as a servant of God the king."
One should not claim to be wiser than the person performing Ifá divination for them.
"What are they doing to Amodu in Ilorin? The goat is still eating like that."
One creates a dove that makes the sound "bẹ̀m̀bẹ̀."
One who beats the dùndún drum cannot deny responsibility for the music it produces.
A person with only one cloth doesn't lend it out to others to dry.
It is better for an elder to die than to be disgraced.
A bird cannot see the water inside a coconut to drink it.
"It is with 'I know it completely' that Oro carries away a man."
"When we are arranging corn, we don't arrange guinea corn at the same time."
"Your younger sibling is sewing clothes for you, yet you claim you don't patronize the seller of ekuru (bean cake); who then patronizes the seller of akara (fried bean cake)?"
"If it were not part of a person's nature (or bad habit), who would wake up in the morning and not wash their face?"
The title "Mother of Education" is an honorific; every mother in the realm of education has her own distinct name/title.
When the soup starts burning, it causes conversation.
"Excess is the father of shame; shame follows excess; an elder who indulges in excess will end in disgrace."
It takes only one day to become disabled/injured; but one suffers the pain every day thereafter.
One should not remain silent and then speak incorrectly; one should not be half-asleep and find someone guilty.
Work within your expertise, beautifier of Ṣàpọ́n
Everyone cries for Banjo, but Banjo does not cry for himself.
It is with its own sword that one kills the tortoise.
"A small child's food can enter an adult's stomach; a small child's ring cannot fit on an adult's finger."
"Pull it inside" is what befits the horseman.
A dog does not go to the deep forest to hunt a tiger/leopard.
The doer knows what they have done to themselves.
A big slap inevitably leads to a fight.
"Today, antelope meat again, tomorrow, antelope meat again; is antelope the only animal in the forest?"
A wife who beats her stepchild is simply looking for conversation (or trouble).
"When someone says 'I've never seen anything like this before,' it means the owner knows his own limits."
"Not having the opportunity to rule is better than saying 'My voice cannot reach the whole town.'"
Borrowed money does not suit one; borrowed trousers do not suit a person; if they don't fit one's legs they become awkward; one's own possessions are what truly suit one.
"What did Daaro own before he claimed he was robbed?"
"The hunter going hunting asks, 'Should I hunt five hundred game or six hundred game?' But which one have you actually caught yet?"
The head of the household won't be so desperate or hungry that he sweeps his own house with his hands.

"Household members don't greet each other with 'Good day household'; visitors aren't greeted with 'Welcome visitor'; whoever doesn't properly greet others with 'Welcome visitor' will lose receiving the 'Good day household' greeting."
What meat have we not eaten before? The frog met us wearing shoes and ended up as a mess.
The one who gets excessively angry provides food for the one who gets mildly angry.
The petty actions of an Ijesa person may seem to hurt but aren't significant.
Who eats while a dog watches hungrily?
The fastidious person eats iwọ; the wise person eats kola nut; the impulsive person eats alligator pepper.
If one refuses to learn from the lessons being taught, one is destined to suffer repeatedly.
"One does not sacrifice to a deity during the harmattan season; if the offering reaches the ground, it will scatter everywhere."
It is the left side
An elder who cannot stand firmly on the ground has wisdom within.
As one tears the apron at the back, one tears one's body in front.
"My clan gave birth to me, a leopard raised me to adulthood, a civet cat adopted me; if there is no meat in the soup, I won't eat."
"Even when fully satiated, even when eating with abandon, using all ten fingers to eat is not befitting of a human being."
"Darkness does not recognize a person of honor; it asks divination for 'Who exactly are you?'"
"When a wife becomes too familiar or defiant with her husband, the mediator withdraws."
The person who is lifted too high will end up ruining themselves.
Treading carefully does not mean one will fail.
One who looks down will find their nose.
"The bead maker leaves beads to accumulate; if the bead owner had demanded immediate payment, it would not be easy to string the beads together later."
One prepares according to one's knowledge and ability; a person without a horse cannot arrive impressively at a gathering.
"One who says 'I know my worth/limits' will not become the subject of mockery or insults."
If you quarrel with the king, expect his vehicle to run over your foot.
"If an elder puts sand in his nose, is it a chicken that will remove it?"

"Hardship doesn't suddenly befall a person from nowhere; suffering doesn't randomly afflict someone; if you walk around in poverty, if you enter town looking destitute, people will serve you water with whatever calabash they find."
Let the sun set so we don't have to argue with the deity of the day.
Though I have grown old and tall, I still appreciate children's play/activities.
A woman does not pay for the medicinal herbs used after a fight.
The face has not seen wealth; it gave birth to a child and named it "Wealth is troublesome".
The size of the rat determines the size of the hole; a wise person does not live recklessly.
The bird that compares itself to the vulture sleeps behind the kitchen.
The chameleon claims it can navigate the path; who has ever walked the path of a chameleon?
Do not rely on the host, do not rely on the guest; it is one's own hand that one relies on.
Masquerade surpasses masquerade; deity surpasses deity; Pààká (a type of masquerade) overpowers the Sango worshipper.
‘I am full’ means ‘I am full,’ ‘I am not full’ means ‘I am not full’; eating excessively is the mark of a greedy elder.
An elder does not finish eating and then say they will eat more.
The person we sell to and use the money to buy a cutlass: he says the suffering of the cutlass is affecting him.
Instead of bowing down to a Fulani, we would rather endure and die.
It is the inability to stop eating that kills the monkey; it is the inability to stop eating that kills the fly; it is the inability to stop eating that kills the antelope.
One does not scratch the ear with a finger, then use it to pick the nose, and then use it to pick the teeth.
The sack behaves like a bag, the skeleton behaves like meat.
The disrespectful person meets disgrace on the way.
An elder who does not greet the chief is tying a rope around his own neck.
A cutlass does not cut without strength; if one has strength, even a cotton child can cut a tree.
Where one places oneself is where one will find comfort
If a eunuch wants to procreate, what can the king do?
A slave does not eat what is not sold in the market.
The hawk does not carry the chick and leave the insect behind.

The person we love is different from the one who claims there is no one like them.
The one who helps you to carry a burden is the one who looks you in the face.
A rope tied to a palm tree is not strong enough to stop an elephant from moving; a rope that claims to stop an elephant from moving is only fooling itself, as the elephant will continue on its path.
If we are pounding yam, the leg will get stained.
A child who has never tasted soup is scooping palm oil into their pocket.
It does not leave the hand of the father and enter the hand of the child
It is expected of everyone to limp a little, but not of the lazy person.
The ruin of one day does not destroy a whole town
Before we start fighting over an inheritance, we should know that the inheritance is not ours.
If the head of the household is struggling, it is the small tree stumps that we use to support him.
A dandy enters the market walking elegantly, a rough person enters the market walking clumsily; it is the rough person who carries the dandy's load home.
The termites and ants are digging, they say they are going to catch a runaway chicken, we shall see.
The pig is not a bird
The chain that is tied to the palm tree is not strong enough to stop the elephant; the rope that tells the elephant not to climb the savannah, it is the elephant that decides where it goes.
The firefly that says it will extinguish the lamp will extinguish itself.
The old crab that is put into a wide-mouthed container is ashamed.
We called you the child of a laughing animal, and you are not smiling; are you the one who should be frowning?
The wealthy walk with the wealthy; like-minded people play together.

One does not keep silent and still speak; one does not look and still miss the way.
Is it as you know it, the bean seller of Sapon?

It is with the sword of the tortoise that we kill the tortoise.

A dog does not go into the wilderness to hunt a leopard.

It is the present that matters

"One masquerade surpasses another masquerade; one deity surpasses another deity; the leopard chased the devotee of Sango into the bush."

"It is refusing-to-leave that kills the housefly; it is refusing-to-leave that kills the moth; it is refusing-to-leave that kills the insect."
"One doesn't use the finger to clean the ear, then use it to clean the nose, and then use it to pick the teeth."
"The shroud pretends to be velvet, while the masquerade pretends to be human."
It is the landlord who is in a hurry that meets the tenant on the road.

"It's lack of arm strength that makes the machete not sharp; if one has arm strength, a cotton thread can cut a tree."

"The person we love is different from the one who claims there's no one like them."

"If we are pounding yam, the pestle will rise up and down."

"It does not get out of the father's hand and then become the child's responsibility."
"It is fitting for everyone to reduce the price of indigo dye, but not for the dye maker."
The spoiling of one day doesn't end in vain/easily.
"The place where we are being told stories before inheriting property, we should know that the inheritance there does not concern us."
"If the head of the household is dancing energetically, one discusses serious matters with the house post/pillar."

"The fashionable person enters the market walking proudly/majestically, the dirty/unkempt person enters the market walking slowly/carefully; it is the dirty person who ends up carrying the fashionable person's load home."
"The cockroach and the ant set out on an expedition; they said they were going to catch a hen, but we only witnessed their departure, not their return."
"The pig does not know beauty/elegance."

"The moth that says it will extinguish the lamp will end up killing itself."
An elderly crab that crawls into a basket of bananas feels ashamed.
"You are called 'child of an elephant' and you're not proud; are you the one who swallowed it?"

Let the slave know themselves as a slave; let the pawn know themselves as a pawn; let the well-behaved person know themselves as God the king's slave.
One should not be wiser than the person for whom one is consulting the Ifá oracle.

"Mother of Káà" is a title of respect; there is no mother in a community who doesn't have a name/reputation.
"When the fire/heat affects the soup, it stirs up conversation."
"Excess is the father of shame; shame is the end result of excess; an elder who wears the garment of excess will end up in shame."
"It takes only one day to become disgraced/shamed; the shame/embarrassment lasts every day."
One does not keep silent and misspeak; one does not stare fixedly and be guilty of wrongdoing.
"Do as you know (how to do), beautiful one of Ṣàpọ́n."

"It is with the tortoise's sword that we kill the tortoise."

The person who has committed a misdeed knows their own wrongdoing.

"The head of the household does not become so poor/desperate that he has to sweep his own compound with his hands."

What meat have we not eaten before? The frog met us wearing shoes, but now it's naked/unadorned.

"It is the elegant/fastidious person who eats the floating 'iwo' food; it is the knowledgeable/wise person who eats kola nut; it is the ignorant/impulsive person who eats 'awusa' (tiger nuts)."
If one is not capable of rejecting the suffering that one is rejecting, one will suffer endless suffering.

It's clear which way the wind is blowing
An elder who doesn't have a foothold on the ground has wisdom inside.
"While one tears the cloth from behind, another tears it from the front."
"The monkey gave birth to me, the leopard raised me, the cat adopted me; if there is no meat in the stew, I will not eat it."

"Darkness doesn't recognize a person of honor; it casts Ifa divination for 'Who are you?'"

"The person who is being carried like a child will end up harming themselves."

If an elder puts mucus in his nose, it is not the chicken that will peck it off.
